comments.body: why are you doing this here?
same comment as above

write this like
``self.dtype = orient != 'table' if dtype is None else dtype``
though still not sure why you cannot actually just set dtype when this is called with orient = table (from above)
@jreback because that is precisely the aim of orient=table: the JSON object specifies itself its dtypes by means of the 'schema'.

BTW, @jreback where could I have a more detailed discussion about the current implementation of pandas JSON serialization? I have found some issues related to JSON spec compliance for non-string column names (#19129).
If your list is very exhaustive I'd suggest sending to the mailing list for back and forth. If it's something that can be summarized in a few checkpoints then an issue would be best
@albertvillanova right, but my point is that we are now checking for the dtype above in read_json, then essentially checking again here. Why cannot we just pass it thru (after its checked once)?
if you have other things you think should be fixed  pls open a new issue

@jreback All default parameter settings (other than those defined in the signature) and inter-dependent constraints are defined at the instantiation of Parser: the default `orient` depending on the self type; `numpy=False` if `orient` is 'split'. That is the reason I put also there the default `dtype` depending on the `orient`.

Therefore, for consistency I would suggest either keeping all default settings as they are here in the Parser, or moving all of them to `read_json`.
@jreback I have finally moved the setting of `dtype` to `read_json`, as you suggested.

But that is not the end of the sentence. The end of the sentence is at line 282:
```
dtype : boolean or dict, default True
    If True, infer dtypes; if a dict of column to dtype, then use those;
    if False, then don't infer dtypes at all, applies only to the data.
```

comments.body: @albertvillanova citing our conversation on the whatsnew - doesn't this signature change affect the other orients? Thought this method was shared across, hence why I was thinking this was an API change

@WillAyd if you look at the implementation of `read_json`, you can check that `dtype` is only used for instantiating JsonReader; JsonReader only uses `dtype` for instantiating either FrameParser or SeriesParser (see method _get_object_parser); and both FrameParser and SeriesParser inherit from Parser, whose constructor sets `self.dtype=True` if `orient != 'table' and dtype is None`, thus recovering the behavior before the PR (default `dtype=True`) for all orients other than 'table'.

Thanks for the explanation. I get your point but find it rather confusing / fragile from a code perspective to have that `None` handling so far removed from the actual user-facing method, hence my hesitation here
Maybe, as @jreback pointed out, it would be more clear to set the default values (False for orient=table, and True for all other orients) in `read_json` table...
